column2: When they were out in the street again, it was still too early to think of going to the hotel for dinner.

column2: How about a movie, Cloudy? asked Allison shyly.

column2: I should love to go. Maybe you won't believe it, but I never went to a movie in my life, and I've been wanting to know what they were like for a long time.

column2: Why, how did it happen? Don't they have moving pictures in your town?

column2: Yes, they have them now, though only a year or so ago.	Yes, they have them now, though only a year or so ago.

column2: But you know I've never been able to get away, even if they had been all about me. Besides, I suppose I should have been considered crazy if I had gone, me, an oldish woman!
column3: But you know I've never been able to get away, even if they had been all about me. Besides, I suppose I should have been considered crazy if I had gone, me, an oldish woman!

column2: If there had been children to take, it would have been different.

column2: I suppose it is a childish desire, but I always loved pictures."

column2: Well, we're going, said Allison.

column2: Get in quick, and I'll have you there before you say Jack Robinson!
column3: Get in quick, and I'll have you there before you say Jack Robinson!

column2: And so in the restful cool of a flower-laden atmosphere in one of the finest moving-picture places in the city Julia Cloud sat with her two children and saw her first moving picture, holding her breath in wonder and delight as the people on the screen lived and moved before her.
column3: And so in the restful cool of a flower laden atmosphere in one of the finest moving picture places in the city Julia Cloud sat with her two children and saw her first moving picture, holding her breath in wonder and delight as the people on the screen lived and moved before her.

column2: I'm afraid I'm having too good a time, she said quietly as she settled back in the car again, and was whirled away to the hotel.

column2: If this keeps on, I won't have dignity enough left to chaperon you properly."

column2: Then after a good dinner they went up to their rooms, and there was Julia Cloud's shining new trunk that had to be looked over; and there on the floor beside it stood two packages, big boxes, both of them.

column2: The cover fell off at last, and the tissue-paper blew up in a great fluff; and out of it rolled a beautiful long, soft, thick gray cloak of finest texture and silken lining, with a great puffy collar and cuffs of deep, soft silver-gray fox.
column3: The cover fell off at last, and the tissue paper blew up in a great fluff; and out of it rolled a beautiful long, soft, thick gray cloak of finest texture and silken lining, with a great puffy collar and cuffs of deep, soft silver gray fox.

column2: Oh-h! was all Julia Cloud could say as the wonderful garment slipped out and spread about over the box and floor.

column2: And then the two children caught it up, and enveloped her in it, buttoning it down the front and turning the collar around her ears.
column3: And then the two children caught it up, and enveloped her in it, buttoning it down the front and turning the collar around her ears.

column2: It's yours, Cloudy, to keep you warm on the journey! cried Leslie, dancing around and clapping her hands.

column2: Oh, isn't she dear?" and Leslie caught her and whirled her around the room.

column2: Then Allison brought the big square box, and demanded that it be opened; and out of it came a small gray hat in soft silky beaver, with a close gray feather curled quietly about it, that settled down on Julia Cloud's lovely white hair as if it had been made for her.
